context:
No a torpedo, as some seem to think, but a platform, which can launch torpedoes/cruse missiles, and/or smaller drones, both air and water, survey defensive staging, likely lay mines, map geology/ topography, coastal and underwater, lay in wait on station for long periods, and one day, become part of a laser defense/offense line/grid.

They might also be used as air defense stations, even doing escort for surface boats/fleets, as outriders and advance warning sensors.

Some of these might also deliver Seals, or pick up personnel from littoral waters or at sea, as well as be used to recover downed airmen or even sailors of damaged boats.

Once the hull and drive manufacturing is in place, the platform can become an ad hoc design, if needed, and the numbers of successful types can be increased to form "pods" that operate as singulars, as needed, or come together for what can only be called wolfpack tactics.

With just a little imagination, developers can turn this tech to many tasks that will force multiply manned boats and strengthen OUR navel forces, even in the event of downsizing from the 200 boat Navy that seems to be needed for National Defense and Our projection of power, across the world.

Iran will blow them up and trump will say everything is under control

context: I've often wondered why we tip our adversaries off as to our present and future capabilities.  Sounds like a cool project but with the amount of money involved one would think "loose lips sink ships"

replies.context: I think it may be for Iran's benefit.  They may not want to stay on the course they're on.

I think it's a bit of misinformation. A few weeks ago a story about Russia testing nuclear capable under water drones broke. I can't imagine the Navy would let their capabilities out. I think we do have weapons launch capability and those range numbers are probably a lot higher.

context: Gimme dat X-LUUV !!
Wonder what this thing uses for fuel?  And how much of that 50 tons is batteries?

We really didn't need to know this. I guess it would be fine to inform us if the development of this weapon is known to countries that are not our allies.  But in general, we should not be exposing weapons like this or how far our hyper-sonic research and development has progressed since 1990.

replies.context: Maintaining a truly "black" program sharply increases it's cost, and rarely works (the Soviets knew about the atomic bomb long before the American public did).  Aside from that, there are good policy reasons to ensure the enemy is aware of our capabilities: it makes them feel less confident about attacking us and tends to avoid destabilization when they eventually find out and may be inclined to panic and do something rash.
But it's fun to watch the public panic and incites actual good new movies.
